title: SUBTASK: Add core UI components for the layout
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Learn how to add and inspect shadcn components.

PARENT TASK: crm-build-tlu (Complete after installing shadcn)

COMPONENTS TO ADD:
1. Card - For organizing content sections
2. Avatar - For user profile display
3. Separator - For visual dividers
4. ScrollArea - For scrollable content

STEP-BY-STEP FOR EACH:
1. Run: npx shadcn@latest add [component-name]
2. Find the new file in components/ui/
3. Read through the component code
4. Identify which Tailwind classes are used
5. Test it by importing and using it somewhere

EXPLORATION QUESTIONS:
- What primitives is each component built on? (Radix UI)
- How are variants/styles handled? (class-variance-authority)
- What props does each component accept?
- How accessible are these components out of the box?

TRY THIS:
Create a simple test page that uses all four components together to see how they look and interact.

CHECKPOINT: You've added Card, Avatar, Separator, and ScrollArea components and understand what each does.

RESOURCES:
- Card: https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/components/card
- Avatar: https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/components/avatar
- Separator: https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/components/separator
- ScrollArea: https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/components/scroll-area

title: Build CRUD operations for contacts
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Master server actions, form handling, and database operations.

TASKS:
1. Create server actions for: createContact, updateContact, deleteContact, getContacts
2. Build a contacts list page with server-side rendering
3. Create a form to add new contacts (use shadcn Form components)
4. Implement edit functionality
5. Add delete with confirmation

LEARNING POINTS:
- Server Actions vs API routes - when to use each?
- Form validation (react-hook-form + zod)
- Optimistic updates
- Revalidation strategies

CHECKPOINT: You should have a fully functional contacts management system.

title: Implement activity/interaction tracking
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Work with timestamps, activity feeds, and audit logs.

TASKS:
1. Create interactions table (notes, calls, emails, meetings)
2. Build a form to log new interactions
3. Display interaction history for each contact
4. Add timestamps and auto-track created_by user
5. Implement an activity feed on dashboard

FEATURES TO CONSIDER:
- Different interaction types
- Rich text notes (simple textarea or markdown?)
- Filtering by interaction type
- Timeline visualization

CHECKPOINT: Users can log and view interaction history for contacts.

title: Add error handling, loading states, and polish
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Learn production-ready patterns and UX improvements.

TASKS:
1. Add proper error boundaries
2. Implement loading skeletons for all data fetching
3. Add toast notifications for actions (success/error)
4. Implement form validation with helpful error messages
5. Add empty states with helpful CTAs
6. Test error scenarios (network failures, invalid data)

UX PATTERNS TO IMPLEMENT:
- Suspense boundaries with loading.tsx
- error.tsx for error handling
- Optimistic UI updates
- Accessible forms and buttons

CHECKPOINT: The app should feel polished with clear feedback for all user actions.

title: Create dashboard with data visualization
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Learn data aggregation and client-side charting.

TASKS:
1. Create a dashboard page with key metrics
2. Write aggregation queries (count contacts, recent activities, etc.)
3. Install and use a charting library (recharts recommended)
4. Build 2-3 simple charts (bar, line, or pie)
5. Make the dashboard responsive

METRICS TO CONSIDER:
- Total contacts and growth over time
- Contacts by company
- Recent interactions
- Pipeline status (if you add deals)

CHECKPOINT: A functional dashboard showing meaningful CRM metrics.

title: SUBTASK: Style and polish the sidebar layout
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Learn design polish, spacing, typography, and color theming.

PARENT TASK: crm-build-tlu (Complete after root layout is working)

WHAT YOU'LL REFINE:
Take your working but basic sidebar and make it look professional.

STEP-BY-STEP:

1. SPACING AND TYPOGRAPHY
   - Adjust padding/margins for better breathing room
   - Set consistent font sizes (text-sm, text-base, etc.)
   - Add proper spacing between nav items
   - Align items consistently

2. COLOR AND THEMING
   - Background colors (sidebar vs main content)
   - Text colors (use Tailwind's semantic colors)
   - Hover states for navigation items
   - Active state colors
   - Border/separator colors

3. ICONS FOR NAVIGATION
   - Install lucide-react if not already
   - Add icons to each nav item (Home, Users, Building, Activity, etc.)
   - Size them appropriately
   - Align with text

4. TRANSITIONS AND INTERACTIONS
   - Add smooth transitions on hover (transition-colors)
   - Polish the active state indicator
   - Ensure good contrast for accessibility

5. FINAL TOUCHES
   - Add a subtle shadow or border to separate sidebar from content
   - Polish the user profile section
   - Ensure everything is visually balanced

DESIGN THINKING:
- Look at real CRMs (HubSpot, Salesforce, Pipedrive) for inspiration
- What makes navigation feel intuitive?
- How much visual weight should the sidebar have?
- Should it be subtle or prominent?

ACCESSIBILITY CHECK:
- Sufficient color contrast?
- Keyboard navigation working?
- Clear focus states?

CHECKPOINT: Your sidebar looks polished and professional, with good spacing, colors, and visual hierarchy.

RESOURCES:
- Tailwind colors: https://tailwindcss.com/docs/customizing-colors
- Lucide icons: https://lucide.dev
- Color contrast checker: https://webaim.org/resources/contrastchecker/

OPTIONAL ENHANCEMENTS:
- Add a logo image
- Tooltip on icon hover
- Badge showing count of new items

title: Set up Zustand for client-side state management
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Understand client-side state management and when to use it vs server state.

TASKS:
1. Install zustand
2. Create your first store (e.g., UI state like sidebar open/closed)
3. Learn the difference between server state and client state
4. Implement a practical use case (modal state, filters, or theme)
5. Understand when to use Zustand vs React Context vs Server State

CONCEPTS TO EXPLORE:
- What is client state vs server state?
- When should you use Zustand vs useState?
- How does Zustand compare to Redux or Context API?
- Persist state to localStorage (optional)

PRACTICAL EXAMPLES TO TRY:
- Sidebar/navigation toggle state
- Filter selections (before they're applied)
- Modal/dialog open/closed state
- User preferences (theme, view mode)

CHECKPOINT: You have at least one working Zustand store managing UI state in your app.

NOTE: Don't use Zustand for data from your database - that's server state handled by Server Components and Actions.

title: SUBTASK: Create root layout wrapper with sidebar
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Understand Next.js layout composition and how layouts wrap pages. PARENT TASK: crm-build-tlu (Complete after building sidebar component) WHAT YOU'LL BUILD: The root layout structure that combines your sidebar with page content. STEP-BY-STEP: 1. UNDERSTAND THE LAYOUT FILE - Open app/layout.tsx (it already exists) - What's currently in it? - How does it relate to pages? 2. PLAN THE LAYOUT STRUCTURE Think about this HTML structure:
{children} ← This is where pages render
3. IMPLEMENT THE LAYOUT - Import your Sidebar component - Set up flexbox container - Make main area scrollable - Add padding to main content area 4. TEST WITH MULTIPLE PAGES - Create a few test pages (app/dashboard/page.tsx, app/contacts/page.tsx) - Navigate between them - Verify sidebar stays consistent and active state changes 5. HANDLE RESPONSIVENESS (Basic) - Does it work on mobile? (It probably doesn't!) - For now, just ensure it doesn't break (you can improve later) - Consider: should sidebar hide on mobile? CONCEPTS TO EXPLORE: - How do layouts in App Router work? - What is the {children} prop? - Why doesn't the sidebar re-render when navigating? - What's the difference between layout.tsx and template.tsx? CHECKPOINT: Your app has a persistent sidebar layout and you can navigate between pages. RESOURCES: - Layouts docs: https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/routing/layouts-and-templates - Flexbox guide: https://css-tricks.com/snippets/css/a-guide-to-flexbox/ BONUS CHALLENGE: Add a simple header bar above the main content with a page title that changes based on the route.

title: Set up project environment variables and Neon database connection
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Understand environment configuration and database connection setup.

TASKS:
1. Create a Neon serverless PostgreSQL database (free tier)
2. Set up .env.local with database connection string
3. Install database client library (pg or @vercel/postgres recommended)
4. Create a simple test connection file to verify database connectivity
5. Document the connection pattern you chose and why

RESOURCES TO EXPLORE:
- Neon console (neon.tech)
- Next.js environment variables docs
- Connection pooling concepts

CHECKPOINT: You should be able to successfully connect to your database and log a test query result.

title: Implement data filtering, sorting, and search
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Learn complex data queries and UI state management.

TASKS:
1. Add search functionality to contacts list
2. Implement column sorting (name, email, date added)
3. Add filters (by company, by status, etc.)
4. Use URL search params to maintain filter state
5. Optimize queries with proper indexes

CONCEPTS TO EXPLORE:
- useSearchParams and useRouter
- SQL query optimization
- Debouncing search input
- Pagination vs infinite scroll

CHECKPOINT: Users should be able to search, filter, and sort their contacts efficiently.

title: Implement authentication with NextAuth.js
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Understand authentication flows and session management.

TASKS:
1. Install and configure NextAuth.js (v5/Auth.js recommended)
2. Set up at least one provider (credentials or OAuth)
3. Create sign-in and sign-up pages
4. Implement protected routes using middleware
5. Store user sessions and understand how they work

CONCEPTS TO EXPLORE:
- JWT vs session-based auth
- Middleware in Next.js App Router
- Password hashing (if using credentials)
- OAuth flow (if using providers)

CHECKPOINT: Users should be able to sign up, sign in, and access protected pages.

title: Set up Zod for form validation and type safety
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Master form validation, type inference, and error handling with Zod.

TASKS:
1. Install zod and @hookform/resolvers
2. Create a schemas directory for validation schemas
3. Build your first schema (e.g., contactSchema with name, email, phone validation)
4. Integrate Zod with react-hook-form
5. Implement custom error messages and validation rules
6. Learn about type inference from schemas

CONCEPTS TO EXPLORE:
- What is schema validation and why use it?
- How does Zod provide type safety?
- Client-side vs server-side validation (do both!)
- Refining schemas with custom validation logic
- Reusing schemas across client and server

PRACTICAL IMPLEMENTATIONS:
- Email format validation
- Phone number formatting
- Required vs optional fields
- String length limits
- Custom business logic validation

INTEGRATION POINTS:
- Use with react-hook-form on client
- Validate Server Action inputs on server
- Share schemas between client/server for type safety

CHECKPOINT: You have reusable Zod schemas integrated with forms, providing type-safe validation on both client and server.

RESOURCES:
- Zod documentation: https://zod.dev
- shadcn form components use Zod + react-hook-form
- Server Actions should always validate inputs with Zod

title: SUBTASK: Create sidebar navigation component
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Build a reusable sidebar with navigation links and understand component composition.

PARENT TASK: crm-build-tlu (Complete after adding UI components)

WHAT YOU'LL BUILD:
A sidebar component (~250px wide) with:
- App logo/title at top
- Navigation menu items (Dashboard, Contacts, Companies)
- Active state highlighting
- User profile section at bottom

STEP-BY-STEP BREAKDOWN:

1. CREATE THE FILE STRUCTURE
   - Where should it live? components/? app/? Think about reusability
   - What should you name it? Sidebar.tsx? AppSidebar.tsx?

2. BUILD THE CONTAINER
   - Fixed width or flexible?
   - What background color?
   - How tall should it be?

3. ADD THE LOGO/HEADER
   - Just text for now or prepare for an image?
   - What size and styling?

4. CREATE NAVIGATION ITEMS
   - Use Next.js Link component
   - How will you structure the menu items data?
   - Should it be hardcoded or from a config array?

5. HIGHLIGHT ACTIVE ROUTE
   - How do you know which page you're on? (usePathname hook)
   - What visual indicator for active state? (background color? border?)

6. ADD USER SECTION AT BOTTOM
   - User Avatar component
   - Name and email
   - Sign out button (non-functional for now)

DESIGN DECISIONS:
- Should navigation items have icons? (if yes, use lucide-react)
- Hover states?
- Collapsed/expanded functionality? (save for later if complex)

CHECKPOINT: You have a Sidebar component that renders a full-height navigation menu with working links.

RESOURCES:
- Next.js Link: https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/components/link
- usePathname: https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/functions/use-pathname
- Lucide icons: https://lucide.dev

title: Add relationship management (contacts to companies)
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Handle complex data relationships and nested forms.

TASKS:
1. Create companies CRUD operations
2. Link contacts to companies (many-to-one relationship)
3. Build a company detail page showing all contacts
4. Add ability to assign/reassign contacts to companies
5. Implement cascade delete considerations

CHALLENGES:
- How do you handle a contact without a company?
- Should you use a select dropdown or autocomplete?
- What happens when a company is deleted?

CHECKPOINT: Contacts and companies should be properly linked with intuitive UI.

title: Initialize shadcn/ui and create base layout components
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Understand component libraries, Next.js layout patterns, and sidebar navigation.

**OVERVIEW:**
You'll build a sidebar-based layout shell that wraps all CRM pages. This is the consistent UI structure users see on every page.

**VISUAL STRUCTURE:**
┌──────┬─────────────────────────┐
│      │  [Header/Title]         │
│ Side │                         │
│ bar  │  Main Content Area      │
│      │                         │
└──────┴─────────────────────────┘

This task has SUBTASKS below (created separately) - complete them in order.

RESOURCES:
- shadcn/ui docs: https://ui.shadcn.com
- Next.js layouts: https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/routing/pages-and-layouts
- Sidebar examples: Search 'shadcn sidebar' for community examples

CHECKPOINT: You have a working sidebar layout that wraps your pages with navigation.

title: SUBTASK: Install and configure shadcn/ui
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Understand how shadcn/ui works and differs from traditional component libraries.

PARENT TASK: crm-build-tlu (Complete this first!)

STEP-BY-STEP:
1. Run the shadcn/ui init command
2. Answer the configuration prompts (style, color scheme, etc.)
3. Examine what files were created/modified
4. Understand the components.json file
5. Test by adding your first component (Button)

CONFIGURATION DECISIONS TO MAKE:
- Which style? (Default or New York)
- Which color scheme? (Slate, Gray, Neutral, etc.)
- CSS variables or Tailwind utility classes?

QUESTIONS TO EXPLORE:
- Where do shadcn components get installed? (Hint: not node_modules!)
- Why does shadcn copy components to your project instead of importing from a package?
- What role does Tailwind play?
- What is components.json used for?

HANDS-ON TASK:
Add the Button component using 'npx shadcn@latest add button'
- Where did the file get created?
- Look at the code - what do you see?
- Import and use it in a page to verify it works

CHECKPOINT: shadcn/ui is configured and you've successfully added and tested the Button component.

RESOURCES:
- Installation: https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/installation/next
- Components: https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/components

title: Design and implement database schema for CRM
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Learn database schema design and migrations.

TASKS:
1. Design tables for: users, contacts, companies, interactions
2. Choose a migration tool (Drizzle ORM or Prisma recommended)
3. Write your first migration to create tables
4. Add relationships between tables (foreign keys)
5. Run the migration against your Neon database

DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS:
- What fields does a contact need?
- How do contacts relate to companies?
- How will you track interactions/activities?
- What indexes might improve performance?

CHECKPOINT: Your database should have a complete schema with proper relationships.
